image.altText: A male academic in glasses standing outside with his arms crossed.

props.synopsis: Almost 90 per cent of Yes voters think First Nations Australians should have a say in matters affecting them. This did not surprise researchers — until they learned 76 per cent of No voters agreed.

title.children: The three findings that surprised this ANU researcher in a 'major' survey to unpack referendum votes

image.altText: A graphic of Tiny Pinder pictured against a dark background with a basketball and a newspaper clipping

props.synopsis: In the early 1990s, the Perth Wildcats were the sporting kings of the city. But that rockstar status may have helped a brutal sexual predator hide in plain sight. WARNING: This story contains details of child sexual abuse.

title.children: Tiny Pinder was a basketball hero. But that helped him hide his brutal sex offending in plain sight

image.altText: Close up of Bruce Lehrmann.

props.synopsis: The former Liberal staffer is facing a fourth day on the stand as part of his defamation trial against Network Ten and journalist Lisa Wilkinson.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann denies evading chief of staff's questions about night of Brittany Higgins's alleged rape

image.altText: Birds fly out the front of Parliament House

props.synopsis: The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters recommends increasing the number of Senate seats for the ACT and the Northern Territory from two to four each, to address population changes and underscore the need for territory representation.

title.children: Federal parliamentary committee recommends doubling number of senators for ACT and Northern Territory

image.altText: Cheng Lei appears on Q+A.

props.synopsis: In the final episode Q+A of 2023, formerly incarcerated journalist Cheng Lei issues a warning about China, and Kalarie man Todd Fernando discusses why the Indigenous Voice to Parliament failed at the referendum.

title.children: 'Don't want naive people going there': Cheng Lei's China warning to Australians

image.altText: The stump of a felled tree at Lane Cove with a person in khaki visible in the background

props.synopsis: Another mass killing of trees has taken place in Longueville on Sydney's lower north shore, just months after more than 200 were cut down in a nearby suburb.

title.children: A mass tree killing on Sydney Harbour is 'worst act of environmental vandalism' locals have seen

image.altText: Mark Butler sitting back in a motorised wheelchair, looking pensive.

props.synopsis: New South Wales is the last of the states to make voluntary assisted dying legal, but the first to give free choice on administering drugs and a shorter wait time.

title.children: From today voluntary assisted dying will be allowed in NSW. Mark wants to be one of the first to access it

image.altText: A soldier sitting on the edge of a tank

props.synopsis: While the pause in hostilities has provided some heartwarming moments, the death and destruction in Gaza could continue for months, write Riley Stuart and Orly Halpern.

title.children: If this was supposed to be an Israel-Hamas ceasefire, strap yourself in

image.altText: A man with a balaclava covering his face holds a gun and speaks with two people standing in Red Cross uniforms.

props.synopsis: The latest group of freed hostages is said to include three French people, two Germans and six Argentinians. Follow live.

title.children: Israel says 11 more Hamas hostages have been freed, as Gaza ceasefire holds

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: More than 600 high-profile Australians publish an open letter against anti-Semitism
Nine children reportedly among latest group of hostages released by Hamas
Israel says 11 more Hamas hostages have been released, as the ceasefire is extended

image.altText: Lightning over a beach.

props.synopsis: Lightning strikes have prevented early flights from taking off at Adelaide airport, as intense rainfall sweeps across the city.

title.children: Thousands without power, flights delayed at Adelaide airport amid thunderstorms

image.altText: Doctor prepares saline drip

props.synopsis: An urgent patient safety alert has been issued to hospitals and clinics, ordering them to stop using two saline products believed to be linked to the outbreak of a dangerous bacteria.

title.children: Death at Queensland hospital suspected to be linked to contaminated saline

image.altText: picture of a man surrounded by smoke after using vape

props.synopsis: Single-use vapes will be banned from being imported into Australia from January in the first stage of a government crackdown against recreational vaping.

title.children: Federal government rolls out timeline for major vaping crackdown

image.altText: a black-and-white close-up of a woman's hand passing a set of car keys to a man

props.synopsis: New research has highlighted the ways perpetrators of violence and coercive control use vehicles — and the paperwork associated with them, like insurance policies — against their partners.

title.children: 'That's a deliberate strategy': How perpetrators of domestic violence can manipulate car insurance to control partners

image.altText: A young woman wearing a black headscarf and black eyeliner looks serious.

props.synopsis: Australians of faith who want to eat less meat can sometimes find themselves torn between their religious identity and environmentalism.

title.children: 'You're going to go to hell': How Lujayn reconciled veganism with her Muslim identity

image.altText: Composite image of Alan Joyce and Kelly Bayer Rosmarin.

props.synopsis: Despite the dire consequences, many of our corporate leaders have yet to grasp the lessons of history and how repeated denials, offloading of responsibility and obfuscation end up coming back to bite, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Pent-up frustration unfolds on corporate Australia

image.altText: Close-up of Australia's five, 10, 20, 50 and 100 dollar bills.

props.synopsis: The Australian dollar has risen to its highest level in nearly four months on increased bets the US Federal Reserve is finished with its interest rate hikes. Follow live.

title.children: ASX to open higher, Australian dollar rises to almost four-month high

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Aussie dollar nearly at a four-month high, gold shines above $US2,000
Australian shares to open flat, ahead of retail data and RBA governor's comments

image.altText: Dozens of people of all ages line up outside a "For Lease" sign at a Sydney apartment building.

props.synopsis: It is now cheaper to buy an apartment than to lease one in many capital cities, according to new analysis that further highlights the ongoing rental affordability crunch for lower-income households.

title.children: 'A depressing set of data': Renters would now be financially better off buying one-third of places they rent

image.altText: A drone image of traffic moving through a roundabout on a cloudy day.

props.synopsis: The power of community advocacy is being celebrated in Melbourne's booming outer north, where a newly built slip lane is shaving off an average of 30 minutes from the morning drive. The locals who championed the change say there are lessons for other growth areas.

title.children: One of Melbourne's worst local traffic jams appears to have been fixed — for now

image.altText: A hissing tabby cat

props.synopsis: A new genetic tool may be crucial to eradicating the millions of feral cats wreaking havoc across Australia — not to mention other pests such as foxes, rabbits, cane toads and carp, writes invasive species management researcher Ellen Cottingham.

title.children: Australia's feral cat  problem could be fixed with powerful new gene editing tools

image.altText: Coloured pills in blister packs

props.synopsis: Antimicrobial resistance is corroding one of the core pillars of modern pharmaceuticals, and it is rampant. Yet we do not know how many AMR incidents are occurring across Australia, nor how many antibiotics are in circulation, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: Growing antibiotic resistance is a grave threat to humanity. Here's what animal farming has to do with it

image.altText: A man wearing a yellow and blue workman uniform holds two planks of wood. Behind him is a party constructed house.

props.synopsis: Wadeye is home to more than 2,000 people and struggles with social issues such as severe overcrowding, which many hope these new builds will help overcome.

title.children: In 2022, dozens of homes were destroyed in this community. Now locals are helping build new ones

image.altText: A close up of a hand holding a mobile phone, which is displaying an apology to customers written on the Optus website.

props.synopsis: The federal government's inquiry into this month's massive Optus outage will hone in on concerns Australians were unable to access the triple-0 emergency service, and whether government messaging during the incident was up to scratch.

title.children: Probe into massive Optus outage to investigate triple-0 access

image.altText: A new born Sumatran rhino gingerly walking over concrete

props.synopsis: The species' population is estimated to be fewer than 50, and conservation groups say there are only about 30 mature animals left.

title.children: Birth of Sumatran rhino cub gives hope to critically endangered species

image.altText: A man stands alongside a younger woman looking unhappy.

props.synopsis: Mariginiup residents return to see the devastation caused by the bushfire that ripped through their community last week, and make a start on picking up the pieces.

title.children: ‘He doesn’t know how to feel’: Strawberry farmer speechless after bushfire ruins everything

image.altText: Palestinian woman cooks in front of her family's  building destroyed in the Israeli bombardment of Gaza

props.synopsis: Mediator Qatar says a deal has been reached to extend a truce between Israeli and Hamas forces in Gaza by two days, continuing a pause in seven weeks of warfare that has killed thousands and laid waste to the Palestinian enclave.

title.children: Deal reached to extend Gaza truce by two days

image.altText: A placard placed next to flowers reads "I am a teacher" posted on a fence

props.synopsis: Teacher Samuel Paty had shown his pupils caricatures of the Prophet Mohammad in a class on freedom of expression, angering some Muslim parents.

title.children: Six teens in French court over alleged connection with beheading of school teacher

image.altText: woman wear a sun hat on the beach

props.synopsis: Brazilian teacher Catiuscia Machado was found in a Chiswick unit on Saturday after police responded to an alleged domestic violence incident.

title.children: Man charged after woman's body found in a bathtub in Sydney's inner west

image.altText: Vacation Vibes vibrators in David Jones

props.synopsis: Sexual devices like vibrators are sold in department stores and pharmacies in some parts of the country. In others they can only be sold in stores hidden from public view and subject to intense restrictions.

title.children: 'Women deserve to buy products they want where they want to buy them': The battle over sex toy sales restrictions

image.altText: A smoker lights up a cigarette

props.synopsis: The generational ban, which would have stopped anyone born after 2009 buying tobacco, has been ditched by New Zealand's new government.

title.children: Health groups angered after New Zealand scraps world-first smoking ban

image.altText: A woman holding a baby stands in a damaged garage.

props.synopsis: The NSW family is staving off homelessness as they battle a complex insurance system, highlighting the red tape barriers vulnerable families can face during disaster recovery.

title.children: Insurance battle keeps refugee family out of home one year after floods

image.altText: Close-up shot of AFLW star Monique Conti smiling straight at the camera as she holds the AFLW best and fairest medal.

props.synopsis: Richmond superstar Monique Conti is the runaway winner of the AFLW best and fairest award, finishing seven votes ahead of her closest rivals for the league's highest honour.

title.children: 'That's the way I like it': How Monique Conti bucked a growing trend to become the AFLW's best and fairest

image.altText: Actress Rachel Zegler gives a sarcastic bow as Lucy Gray in the Hunger Games prequel.

props.synopsis: Uli grew up in post-war Germany, so the possibility of a Hunger Games like dystopia feels like 'a very real thing'. This is how the film's Production Designer tackled the prequel.

title.children: Uli grew up in post-war Germany. This is how it influenced his designs on the new Hunger Games
